newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai soybean ends mixed in slow trading.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai soybean ends mixed in slow trading.

text.p: Shanghai soybean futures ended mixed in slow trading on Tuesday due to an uncertain short-term market trend, traders said.

The key November 1996 contract ended at 3,296 yuan ($396) per tonne, rising seven yuan. It opened at an intra-day high of 3,297 and hit a low of 3,276. January fell nine to 3,240 yuan per tonne, March 20 to 3,270 and May rose 18 to 3,310.
Combined volume fell to 8,400 tonnes from 18,700.
Traders said many investors were wary about the short-term market trend with poor long-term fundamentals limiting the potential for technical rebounds in the short term.
"Short-covering pushed the prices up but they met resistance at high levels due to weak market sentiment," one trader said.
"Slow trading indicated that long position holders lacked confidence," he added.
Traders said the November contract will rise further if it breaches the key 3,300 yuan resistance, but the long-term pessimistic view will remain.
"Over-supply of domestic spot soybeans makes many investors hesitate to build long positions at current levels," a second trader said.
